docs.lead_paragraph: One of the issues that never gets adequate attention is maternal mortality in the developing world, and partly for that reason it's one of the topics that Casey and I will be reporting on. It's simply a scandal that the number of women dying in childbirth around the world has been stuck at half a million for 15 years now -- when we know exactly how to get that number down.

docs.lead_paragraph: Pregnant women who do not get enough vitamin E may give birth to children who are at higher risk of developing asthma, a new study finds. Other studies have offered mixed results about whether taking the vitamin may help people with breathing problems. The authors of the new report say it appears there may be an early window when taking it makes the most difference.

headline.main: Prenatal Vitamins and Asthma in Children

docs.abstract: University of Aberdeen, Scotland, researchers conduct study on children that suggests that mothers who do not get enough vitamin E early in pregnancy may have children at higher risk of developing asthma; study is published in American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK The News -- Katie Couric made her debut as a network news anchor. Behind the News -- The reviews were mixed for Ms. Couric, with many critics describing her first broadcast as a journalistic hodgepodge, mixing the serious (a report from Afghanistan) with the not-so-serious (a first photo of Tom Cruise's baby). For all the buildup about a new era at CBS News, in the end her broadcast didn't seem all that different from the others. But the opening night audience, estimated at 13.6 million viewers, was the largest for the network's signature newscast in eight years. DETROIT The News -- The Ford Motor Company brought in an aircraft industry executive, Alan J. Mulally, to help run it. Behind the News -- For William Clay Ford Jr., the company's chairman, the move was an admission that Ford needed new approaches to increase sales and profits. But some strategies Mr. Mulally adopts may end up sounding familiar to Ford executives. In overhauling the commercial aircraft business at Boeing, where he worked for 37 years, Mr. Mulally studied some Ford projects, including the development of the Taurus in the mid-1980's. MEXICO The News -- Mexico's highest electoral court declared Felipe Calderón the country's new president, after two months of dispute. Behind the News -- Mr. Calderón, a conservative who will take office Dec. 1, reached out to supporters of his leftist rival, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, saying he was open to some of their ideas. But Mr. López Obrador, whose claim of widespread voting fraud was rejected by the court, would have none of it. He refused to recognize Mr. Calderón's victory and plans to establish an alternative government. JAPAN The News -- Princess Kiko gave birth to a boy, defusing a debate in Japan about whether women should be allowed to ascend to the imperial throne. Behind the News -- The infant, as yet unnamed, was the first male born in the imperial family in 41 years. Both Princess Kiko and her sister-in-law, Crown Princess Masako, have daughters, but under the imperial system they cannot become empress. A panel of experts last year had recommended the system be changed, but action on the recommendations was postponed when Princess Kiko's pregnancy was announced. WASHINGTON The News -- Ronald Reagan will return to Washington in the form of a statue at the National Statuary Hall in the Capitol. Behind the News -- The good news for fans of Mr. Reagan was bad news for the admittedly fewer fans of another Republican, Thomas Starr King, whose bronze will be removed. King, a Civil War-era California politician who preached national unity, fell victim to rules allowing only two statues per state. In approving plans to enshrine Mr. Reagan, the California Legislature decided that the missionary Junipero Serra could stay, but that King had to go.

headline.main: New Kids on the Block | Sept. 3-9
